message.content:
We start by identifying the key numbers from each statement.

1. Operating Cash Flow to Net Income Ratio

 • From the cash flow statement, the “Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities” is –4,504,752.68.

 • From the income statement, the “Net Profit” is 111,731.83.

 • The ratio is calculated as:
  Ratio = (Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities) / (Net Profit)
    = –4,504,752.68 / 111,731.83 ≈ –40.32
  Note: In the provided example both values were negative so the negatives canceled. Here, the negative operating cash flow versus positive net profit gives a negative ratio.

2. Current Assets Turnover Ratio

 • In the sample solution this “Turnover Ratio” was computed as Total Revenue divided by Ending Current Assets.
 • For our data:
  Total Revenue = 791,992.51 (from the income statement)
  Ending Total Current Assets = 9,122,854.19 (from the balance sheet)
 • Thus:
  Ratio = 791,992.51 / 9,122,854.19 ≈ 0.0869, which rounds to 0.09

3. Quick Ratio

 • The Quick Ratio considers only the most liquid current assets (cash, bank deposits, interest receivable and accounts receivable) divided by current liabilities.
 • From the balance sheet:
  Cash on Hand = 927,447.32
  Bank Deposits = 71,662.08
  Interest Receivable = 5,264.70
  Accounts Receivable = 248,540.09
  Sum of “quick” assets = 927,447.32 + 71,662.08 = 999,109.40; then add Interest Receivable: 999,109.40 + 5,264.70 = 1,004,374.10; then add Accounts Receivable: 1,004,374.10 + 248,540.09 = 1,252,914.19
 • Current Liabilities are the sum of:
  Accounts Payable = 3,350,120.00
  Taxes Payable = 39,599.66
  Total = 3,389,719.66
 • Thus:
  Quick Ratio = 1,252,914.19 / 3,389,719.66 ≈ 0.3698 which rounds to 0.37

We therefore have:

{"solution": {"Operating Cash Flow to Net Income Ratio": "-40.32", "Current Assets Turnover Ratio": "0.09", "Quick Ratio": "0.37"}}
